docs.title: NARLA User Guide & User Manual
docs.text: Welcome to NARLA (AI-Driven Apartment Co-Pilot) 👋 NARLA helps roommates manage shared apartment life—chores, bills, groceries, and reminders—in one simple place.

docs.title: What NARLA Helps You Do
docs.text:
• Create a household and invite roommates
  • Assign, schedule, and track chores
  • Add bills and split them fairly
  • Track shared groceries and inventory
  • Send reminders so nothing gets forgotten

docs.title: Who This Manual Is For
docs.text:
• Students sharing an apartment
  • Roommates sharing expenses and tasks
  • Anyone who wants less stress around “who’s doing what”

docs.title: Start Here
docs.text:
• New user? Go to Getting Started
  • Need setup help? Go to Installation & Access
  • Want an overview? Go to App Tour
  • Need help now? Go to Troubleshooting or FAQ

docs.title: App Tour (What each screen does)
docs.text: This section explains what you’ll see inside NARLA.

docs.title: Dashboard (Home)
docs.text: The dashboard shows your household at a glance: - Today’s chores - Upcoming bills - Grocery items running low - Recent activity

docs.title: Household Tab
docs.text: This is where you: - See all roommates - Add/remove members (if admin) - Change household settings

docs.title: Chores Tab
docs.text: This is where you: - Add chores - Assign chores - Mark chores complete - See history and reminders

docs.title: Bills Tab
docs.text: This is where you: - Add bills and due dates - Split costs - Track payment status

docs.title: Groceries / Inventory Tab
docs.text: This is where you: - Add shared items - Track quantities - See “low stock” alerts

docs.title: Notifications
docs.text:
You can receive reminders for: - Upcoming chores - Overdue bills - Low inventory items

Notifications can be adjusted in Settings.

docs.title: Bills
docs.text: NARLA helps you track shared bills and reduce “who still owes me?” situations.

docs.title: Adding a Bill
docs.text:
1. Go to Bills
  2. Tap Add Bill
  3. Enter:
  4. Bill name (ex: “Internet”)
  5. Amount (ex: $60)
  6. Due date
  7. Who paid (optional)
  8. Split method
  9. Tap Save

docs.title: Split Methods (Simple Explanation)
docs.text:
Common options: - Equal split: everyone pays the same - Custom split: different amounts for different roommates

Examples: - Equal split: $120 / 3 roommates → $40 each - Custom split: Roommate A pays $50, Roommate B pays $30, Roommate C pays $40

docs.title: Marking Payments
docs.text: When someone pays: 1. Open the bill 2. Mark their share as Paid 3. The bill updates automatically

docs.title: Good Practices
docs.text:
• Add bills as soon as they arrive
  • Add due dates so reminders work
  • Keep bill names consistent (ex: always “Electricity”)

docs.title: If Someone Pays Late
docs.text: You can: - Send a reminder notification - Add a note to the bill history (if supported)

docs.title: Chores
docs.text: Chores keep everyone accountable and reduce arguments.

docs.title: Creating a Chore
docs.text:
1. Go to Chores
  2. Tap Add Chore
  3. Fill in:
  4. Name (ex: “Take out trash”)
  5. Assigned roommate
  6. Due date or schedule (daily/weekly)
  7. Notes (optional)
  8. Tap Save

docs.title: Assigning Chores Fairly
docs.text:
Good practice: - Rotate chores weekly - Assign based on availability - Keep chores small and clear

Example rotation: - Week 1: Trash → Roommate A - Week 2: Trash → Roommate B - Week 3: Trash → Roommate C

docs.title: Marking a Chore Complete
docs.text:
1. Open the chore
  2. Tap Mark Complete
  3. Add optional comment (ex: “Done at 9pm”)

docs.title: Recurring Chores
docs.text: Use recurring schedules for things like: - Trash (weekly) - Bathroom clean (weekly) - Dishes (daily)

docs.title: Chore Reminders
docs.text:
Reminders can be: - Push notifications - Email notifications - In-app alerts

You can adjust reminders in Notifications.

docs.title: Do all roommates need accounts?
docs.text: Yes. Each roommate needs an account so chores and bills can be tracked fairly.

docs.title: Can I join multiple households?
docs.text: If your team limits to one household per account, then no. If your team supports multiple, explain how switching works.

docs.title: What happens if someone moves out?
docs.text: Admins can remove them. Bills and chore history remain for record-keeping.

docs.title: Can I edit or delete a chore/bill?
docs.text: Yes, if your app supports it. Typically the creator (or admin) can edit/delete.

docs.title: Does NARLA handle real money payments?
docs.text: Usually no—NARLA tracks who owes what. If you support payments, explain clearly: - What providers you use - Whether card info is stored (usually it should not be)

docs.title: Is my data private?
docs.text: Only household members should see household data. Passwords are never visible.

docs.title: What if someone refuses to mark chores complete?
docs.text: The system can show who is overdue. The best fix is household agreement + reminders.

docs.title: What devices are supported?
docs.text: Any modern browser. Mobile support depends on release platform.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This page helps you start using NARLA quickly, even if you’re new.

docs.title: 1) Create Your Account
docs.text:
1. Open NARLA
  2. Tap Sign Up
  3. Enter your email and a secure password
  4. Verify your email (if prompted)
  5. Log in

Tip: Use an email you actually check—NARLA may send invites and reminders.

docs.title: 2) Create or Join a Household
docs.text:
A household is your shared apartment group.

You can either: - Create a household (if you’re the first roommate), or - Join a household (if a roommate already created it)

docs.title: 3) Add Your Roommates
docs.text: Once the household exists: - Invite roommates by email or - Share a join code / invite link

docs.title: 4) Do Your First “Real” Actions
docs.text:
Try these in order: 1. Add 2–3 chores (trash, dishes, vacuum) 2. Add a bill (internet, electricity) 3. Add 2–3 groceries (milk, eggs, rice)

After that, you’re basically fully set up.

docs.title: Common First-Day Questions
docs.text:
• “Do we all need accounts?” → Yes, each roommate needs an account.
  • “Can we change who pays?” → Yes, bills can be edited later.
  • “Can we turn off reminders?” → Yes, in settings.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
Household A shared group for one apartment/home. Roommates share chores, bills, groceries.

Roommate / Member A person inside your household.

Admin A household member with permission to manage members/settings (if supported).

Chore A task like trash, dishes, cleaning.

Recurring chore A chore that repeats on a schedule (daily/weekly).

Bill A shared expense like rent, utilities, internet.

Split How a bill is divided between roommates (equal/custom).

Inventory A shared list of items in the household (groceries/supplies).

docs.title: Groceries & Inventory
docs.text: NARLA helps track shared groceries so you don’t run out unexpectedly.

docs.title: Adding Items
docs.text:
1. Go to Groceries / Inventory
  2. Tap Add Item
  3. Enter:
  4. Item name (ex: “Milk”)
  5. Quantity (ex: 1)
  6. Optional: category (dairy, snacks)
  7. Tap Save

docs.title: Updating Quantity
docs.text:
When someone uses an item: - Decrease quantity (ex: milk from 1 → 0)

When you restock: - Increase quantity (ex: eggs 0 → 1)

docs.title: Low Stock Alerts
docs.text: If enabled, NARLA notifies you when: - Quantity hits 0 - Quantity drops below a threshold (ex: “below 2”)

docs.title: Shared Rules That Prevent Conflicts
docs.text: Recommended: - Use the inventory only for shared items - If something is personal, don’t add it as shared - Agree on who buys what categories

docs.title: Households & Roommates
docs.text: A household is the shared group for one apartment or shared living space.

docs.title: Creating a Household
docs.text:
1. Go to Household
  2. Select Create Household
  3. Enter:
  4. Household name (ex: “12C at University Edge”)
  5. Optional address/notes
  6. Tap Create

docs.title: Joining a Household
docs.text:
1. Get the join code or invite link from a roommate
  2. Go to Join Household
  3. Enter the code or open the link
  4. Confirm

docs.title: Inviting Roommates
docs.text: From the Household screen: - Tap Invite - Send via email or copy join code

docs.title: Roles (Admin vs Member)
docs.text: Some households have roles: - Admin: can manage members and settings - Member: can use chores/bills/groceries normally

docs.title: Removing a Roommate
docs.text: Admins can remove members if someone moves out: - Household → Members → Select member → Remove

docs.title: Installation & Access
docs.text: NARLA can be accessed as a web app (and may also have a mobile app release).

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Internet connection
  • A modern browser: Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Edge
  • Phone or laptop

docs.title: Accessing NARLA
docs.text:
1. Open the NARLA URL provided by your team
  2. Tap Log In or Sign Up

If your team publishes a mobile app later: - Download from the App Store / Google Play - Log in using the same account

docs.title: Troubleshooting Access
docs.text: If the page won’t load: - Confirm you’re connected to Wi-Fi - Try a different browser - Turn off ad blockers temporarily - Check Troubleshooting

docs.title: Notifications
docs.text: Notifications help your household stay on track.

docs.title: What NARLA Can Notify You About
docs.text:
• Upcoming chores
  • Overdue chores
  • Bills due soon
  • Unpaid bills
  • Groceries running low

docs.title: Managing Notification Settings
docs.text:
Go to: Settings → Notifications

You may be able to toggle: - Push notifications (phone) - Email notifications - Quiet hours (no alerts overnight)

docs.title: Recommended Settings
docs.text: Most roommates like: - Chore reminders: 12–24 hours before due - Bill reminders: 3 days before due - Low-stock alerts: enabled

docs.title: Settings & Privacy
docs.text: This page explains account settings and what data is visible.

docs.title: Account Settings
docs.text: In Settings you can typically: - Change name and profile details - Change password - Update notification preferences

docs.title: Household Visibility
docs.text:
Household members may see: - Your chore assignments and completion status - Your bill payment status (paid/unpaid) - Shared grocery updates

They should NOT see: - Your private password - Payment card details (if your app doesn’t store them) - Other households (if multi-household is not supported)

docs.title: Privacy Notes (Simple)
docs.text: NARLA is designed so that: - Only household members can view household data - You can leave a household if you move out - Admins can manage membership

docs.title: Leaving a Household
docs.text: If supported: - Settings → Household → Leave Household

docs.title: Accessibility
docs.text: If your team supports accessibility features, list them here: - Dark mode - Larger text - High contrast

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: If something is not working, use this checklist.

docs.title: Login Problems
docs.text: Issue: “I can’t log in.” Try: - Confirm email/password - Reset password - Check if your email needs verification - Try a different browser

docs.title: Household Invite Problems
docs.text: Issue: “The code doesn’t work.” Try: - Confirm you typed it correctly (no spaces) - Ask for a fresh invite link - Confirm you aren’t already in another household (if limited to one)

docs.title: Chores Not Updating
docs.text: Try: - Refresh the page - Log out and log back in - Check your internet connection

docs.title: Bills Math Looks Wrong
docs.text: Try: - Confirm number of roommates - Confirm split type (equal vs custom) - Confirm the total amount is correct

docs.title: Notifications Not Coming
docs.text: Try: - Turn on notifications in your phone settings - Check NARLA notification settings - Try email reminders if push is off

docs.title: Still Stuck?
docs.text: Use the FAQ or contact your team’s support method (email/issue tracker).
